column5: I thought the boating exam thing was discussed on here earlier, and it's not a requirement for tourists, unless you stay a certain (long) period of time. Am I wrong or has something changed?
Mohl,You are correct.https://www.walleyecentral.com/forums...t=boating+examIn short, if you are meet the requirements of your home state, you are legal in Canada.Nimstug

I googled the boater card since I not heard about this new requirement. It will apply to us residents as of Sept 09 but non-residents are exempt for 45 consecutive days. So unless you are here for a long time (more than one trip would not be consecutive days) it sounds like you're off the hook.
It looks like the hunt-fish cards only apply to Ontario province.

I called the Outdoor Card Centre today. The gentleman that answered the phone was very helpful. He said, that the final details of how things will work have not been communicated to the Outdoor Card Centre. However he did say, this is what he expects to happen: For 2009 that non-residents would buy the their fishing license "just as in past years". At that time a form/application would be filled out for an Outdoors card. A $9 fee for the 3 year card will be collected. Applicants then will eventually receive an Outdoors Card in the mail. For 2010 Non-Resident Outdoors card holders (now possessing the required unique ID numbers) then would be able to order Fishing Licenses via the Internet. JDP

Just received a newsletter from our camp, $9.00 fee for fish/hunt card for 3 year for Ontario. Also the camp rise their fee another $ 20.00. Still going back next year, but might lose some more people because of all the increased cost.

So the bottom line is, besides a passort to get back into the US we will need these new cards when we enter Canada next year?

The following text is from http://www.mnr.gov.on.ca/en/Business...ge/260308.html The Ministry of Natural Resources (MNR) is working on a project to improve the fishing and hunting licensing system. Once these improvements are complete, anglers and hunters will be able to purchase Ontario fishing and hunting licences from home, using the Internet or the automated toll-free phone system. As part of this project, MNR will also be developing an automated licensing system for licence issuers to improve service to anglers and hunters. The automated system will mean that all anglers and hunters will need a unique identification number. That is why MNR will be extending the requirement to have an Outdoors Card to non-resident anglers and hunters, effective January 1, 2009. The Outdoors Card will be required to purchase an Ontario fishing or hunting licence, except for a one-day fishing licence. ______________________ Information about Ontario fishing licence options for non Canadian residents in 2009 is available - seehttp://www.mnr.gov.on.ca/en/Business...02_165336.html ______________________ More information about the Outdoors Card is available from the Outdoors Card Centre (toll free) at 1-800-387-7011 from anywhere in North America. The hours of operation of the Outdoors Card Centre are Monday to Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. (Eastern Time). The Outdoors Card website is http://outdoorscard.mnr.gov.on.ca/
